subject: Re: [junit] Is the error cos of Classpath or my Program??
msgSnippet: On Sun, 2002-11-03 at 14:56, vivek srinivasan wrote: Make sure that the directory with your class files is on the classpath. Most/all IDEs will take care of
messageBody:
On Sun, 2002-11-03 at 14:56, vivek srinivasan wrote:

Make sure that the directory with your class files is on the classpath.
Most/all IDEs will take care of that for you... at least Eclipse will.

I have a couple commetns on your tet though:

> 2. TestFibonacci.java which is the test program
> import junit.framework.*;
>
> public class TestFibonacci extends TestCase {
> Fibonacci f;
>
> public TestFibonacci(String name) {
> super(name);
> }
>
> public void setUp(){
> f=new Fibonacci();
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> return new TestSuite(TestFibonacci.class);
> }

Why are you doing this explicitly? TestCase will take care f this for
you. Also, use the varient that takes a message:

> public void test1() {
> assertTrue(f.compute(1)==1);
> }

Use assertEquals instead, you get much better diagnostics:

public void test1() {
assertEquals("compute(1) returned bad result.", 1, f.compute(1));
}

Have a look at the Assert API, there's a fair selection of assertions..
much more than assertTrue().

Dave
--
